comment.body: @potsrevennil I don't think this was intentional, but upon consideration, it may be the right call -- those CBMC proofs tend to be computationally expensive, and each line still conducts all proofs for a fixed K=2,3,4.

## t4g.small

### MLKEM top-level benchmarks from MLKEM-C-AArch64 (https://github.com/pq-code-package/mlkem-c-aarch64/commit/b84f0a307f869de21a3e5299653e8f5289579bea)

```
MLKEM512
keypair cycles=0
encaps cycles=0
decaps cycles=0
```

```
CRYPTO_CIPHERTEXTBYTES: 768

MLKEM768

encaps cycles=284609
decaps cycles=351402

CRYPTO_PUBLICKEYBYTES: 1184
CRYPTO_CIPHERTEXTBYTES: 1088
```

This is probably something related to the PMU registers... but I have never seen such a behavior before...

comment.body:
Okay, I managed to reproduce this on my RPi4. So this is unrelated to the CI. 

My initial suspision is that this is due to the process being scheduled to another core in which case we could resolve it by `taskset` to a specific core. 

I will test that a bit more.

issue.title: Makefile should properly keep track of variables
issue.body:
If you are currently running 
```
tests bench
```
(implying `--cycles NO`), followed by 
```
tests bench --cycles PMU
```
it won't work because the Makefile does not properly keep track of those variables and won't rebuild the binaries. 

The way to solve this is to keep the variables of the previous builds in a file and re-build in case any of those change as we have implemented, for example, 
here: https://github.com/pq-code-package/mlkem-c-embedded/blob/e1ab38d94529eb6a43705cf7dd938879b177ea07/mk/config.mk#L22.

issue.title: `tests bench` script should fail if binaries fail
issue.body:
**Issue:** `scripts/tests/bench` does not fail if the benchmarking binaries fail.

Example output:
```
~/repos/mlkem-c-aarch64$ ./scripts/tests bench --cycles PERF
INFO  > benchmark
INFO  > make CYCLES=PERF test/bin/bench_kyber512
INFO  > MLKEM512 passed
INFO  > make CYCLES=PERF test/bin/bench_kyber768
INFO  > MLKEM768 passed
INFO  > make CYCLES=PERF test/bin/bench_kyber1024
INFO  > MLKEM1024 passed
MLKEM512

MLKEM768

MLKEM1024
```

Here, the issue was that access to `perf` was missing, as witnessed when running the binaries separately:
```
~/repos/mlkem-c-aarch64$ ./test/bin/bench_kyber1024
read: Bad file descriptor
```

Another issue is that switching between `CYCLES=NO/PMU/PERF` requires `make clean` and rebuild, which is not yet documented.

**Task:**
- [ ]  Fix `tests` so that it fails if the test/bench binaries fail. Ideally, don't mask `stderr`.
- [ ] Document that `make clean` is needed when switching between `NO/PERF/PMU`, or -- even better -- detect the switch and rebuild automatically.

comment.body: https://github.com/pq-code-package/mlkem-c-aarch64/pull/69 solved the first task by the way.

Another issue is that switching between `CYCLES=NO/PMU/PERF` requires `make clean` and rebuild, which is not yet documented.

**Task:**

issue.title: `tests bench` script should fail if binaries fail
issue.body:
**Issue:** `scripts/tests/bench` does not fail if the benchmarking binaries fail.

Example output:
```
~/repos/mlkem-c-aarch64$ ./scripts/tests bench --cycles PERF
INFO  > benchmark
INFO  > make CYCLES=PERF test/bin/bench_kyber512
INFO  > MLKEM512 passed
INFO  > make CYCLES=PERF test/bin/bench_kyber768
INFO  > MLKEM768 passed
INFO  > make CYCLES=PERF test/bin/bench_kyber1024
INFO  > MLKEM1024 passed
MLKEM512

MLKEM768

MLKEM1024
```

Here, the issue was that access to `perf` was missing, as witnessed when running the binaries separately:
```
~/repos/mlkem-c-aarch64$ ./test/bin/bench_kyber1024
read: Bad file descriptor
```

Another issue is that switching between `CYCLES=NO/PMU/PERF` requires `make clean` and rebuild, which is not yet documented.

**Task:**
- [x]  Fix `tests` so that it fails if the test/bench binaries fail. Ideally, don't mask `stderr`.
- [ ] Document that `make clean` is needed when switching between `NO/PERF/PMU`, or -- even better -- detect the switch and rebuild automatically.

comment.body:
I set the `CPUAffinity` for the github runner service on the RPi4 to a fixed core. 
I ran the benchmarks a few times and it seems to work: https://github.com/pq-code-package/mlkem-c-aarch64/actions/runs/9608920435
https://github.com/pq-code-package/mlkem-c-aarch64/actions/runs/9608985390/job/26502685935

If you are running the benchmarks locally, maybe you want to do a `taskset 1 tests bench --cycles PMU`.

comment.body:
## Reconciliation completed

#### âœ… The reconciliation completed successfully and all changes have been applied across the services!

## Changes applied
    
### Github

- **rod-chapman** is now a member of team **pqcp-contributors**

issue.title: Add coeff_signed_to_unsigned() functions and its proof
issue.body:
This PR adds _only_ the coeff_signed_to_unsigned() function in poly.c and its proof.

This was previously added in support of the proof of poly_compress(), but that proof is blocked pending CBMC bug fixes.

This PR adds coeff_signed_to_unsigned() in isolation so that proofs of other functions may proceed, such as poly_tobytes()

To run proofs, cd to "cbmc/proofs/coeff_signed_to_unsigned", then either

1. "make" (runs with litani and cbmc-viewer)
or
2. "make -f desktop.mk" (run with command-line CBMC tools only - best for inspecting details results.)

comment.body:

By the way, here are the errors that I extracted from the artifact I uploaded to my fork.

issue.title: Add coeff_signed_to_unsigned() functions and its proof
issue.body:
This PR adds _only_ the coeff_signed_to_unsigned() function in poly.c and its proof.

This was previously added in support of the proof of poly_compress(), but that proof is blocked pending CBMC bug fixes.

This PR adds coeff_signed_to_unsigned() in isolation so that proofs of other functions may proceed, such as poly_tobytes()

To run proofs, cd to "cbmc/proofs/coeff_signed_to_unsigned", then either

1. "make" (runs with litani and cbmc-viewer)
or
2. "make -f desktop.mk" (run with command-line CBMC tools only - best for inspecting details results.)

comment.body:
OK... thanks for that data. If I run "make" locally (within a NIX shell), then look in the logs/result.xml file, I see things like:
```
<result property="coeff_signed_to_unsigned.postcondition.1" status="SUCCESS">
  <location file="/Users/rodchap/Desktop/rod/projects/crypto/pqcp/aarch64-rod-main/mlkem/poly.h" function="coeff_signed_to_unsigned" line="53" working-directory="/Users/rodchap/Desktop/rod/projects/crypto/pqcp/aarch64-rod-main/cbmc/proofs/coeff_signed_to_unsigned"/>
</result>
```
which shows the same proofs succeeding. Still no idea _why_ they are failing in CI... :-(

issue.title: Gather performance data from different instance sizes

comment.body: @hanno-becker [if you could try this on a fork](https://github.com/marketplace/actions/on-demand-self-hosted-aws-ec2-runner-for-github-actions) and get the configuration set how you like it using your credentials, when I have those credentials, I'll have an easier lift.
